did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Urban Poverty Program, Deputy Director, Office Files of Gordon L. Berlin
did.abstract: The Urban Poverty (UP) Program was established as a subdivision of the United States and International Affairs Program (USIAP) in October 1981, taking over programs formerly administered by the divisions of National Affairs and Education and Public Policy. It administered programs benefiting the poor and inner-city residents in areas that included community development, employment and training, welfare, teen pregnancy, poverty, crime, and precollege education. In 1988, UP became a separate division, and in 1996, was merged into the Asset Building and Community Development Program (ASSETS). Gordon L. Berlin served as a Program Officer in the Urban Poverty Program from 1982 to 1987 and as its Deputy Director from 1987 until he left the Foundation in June 1988. He oversaw programs in employment, training, labor supply, welfare, and related educational issues. He also served on task forces, such as the Foundation's Task Force on Growth, Development and Employment (1984-1987) and the National Service Task Force (1984-1986). The Office Files of Gordon L. Berlin primarily consists of Program Files containing reports, data, research, notes, memoranda, and correspondence relating to such issues as national service, summer youth employment, workfare/welfare reform, remedial education and workplace literacy, preschool education and daycare, and school drop-out rates of at-risk youth. There are also some conference materials, subject and correspondence files, and a few speeches and writings relating to these and similar issues.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

bioghist.head: Organizational History
bioghist.p: The work of what became the Urban Poverty Program began when the Public Affairs Program was formally established in 1952. One of the goals of the new program was to work toward greater equality of opportunity for minority groups. In 1965, Public Affairs was succeeded by the National Affairs Division, created to focus on deep-rooted problems facing American society. Program areas under the National Affairs Division included Social Development and Urban and Metropolitan Development. In 1981, a reorganization of the Foundation replaced National Affairs with the United States and International Affairs Program (USIAP).

The Urban Poverty Program was established in October 1981 as a subdivision of USIAP, taking over programs formerly administered by the divisions of National Affairs and Education and Public Policy. It administered programs benefiting the poor and inner-city residents in areas that included community development, employment and training, welfare, teen pregnancy, poverty, crime, and precollege education. It also assumed oversight of the programs in Population and of new programs to combat infant and child mortality. The Urban Poverty Program became a program area within a newly organized Program Division in 1988 and was merged into the Asset Building and Community Development Program (ASSETS) in 1996.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Gordon L. Berlin received a B.A. from University of Charleston (1974) and an M.A. from George Washington University in Science, Technology and Public Policy (1976). Prior to joining the Ford Foundation in 1982, he worked for the Office of Research and Development in the U.S. Department of Labor. Mr. Berlin served as a program officer in the Urban Poverty Program from 1982 to 1987 and as its Deputy Director until June 1988 when he left the Foundation. He oversaw programs in employment, training, labor supply, welfare, and related educational issues.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into 4 series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Office Files of Gordon L. Berlin document his work as a Program Officer (1982-1987) and as Deputy Director of the Urban Poverty Program (1987-1988). Throughout his time with the Foundation, his work focused on labor and unemployment issues. In addition, Mr. Berlin served on task forces, such as the Foundation's Task Force on Growth, Development and Employment (1984-1987) and the National Service Task Force (1984-1986). He also continued to research and write about the difficulties of the school-to-work transition for economically and educationally disadvantaged young adults (1985).

This small series consists of four Conference files. They hold information retained by Mr. Berlin about conferences he organized or attended, including reports on events, agenda, lists of participants, and related correspondence. The conferences include the Aspen Institute and Public Agenda Foundation conference at the Wye Plantation, MD (1982), the Computer Education Conference in Bangor, MA (1983), the National Service Meeting in New York, NY (1983), and the Russell Sage Foundation Poverty Meeting in New York, NY (1987).

The largest series in the collection, the Program Files consist of reports, data, research, notes, memoranda, and correspondence on a variety of subjects related to Foundation program activity. Arranged alphabetically by subject, the files document Mr. Berlin's work relating to labor, welfare, and education. Multiple files on the same subject have been arranged chronologically.

Several files pertain to Mr. Berlin's previous interest in welfare reform, the retraining of industrial workers for employment in other fields, and preparing impoverished youth for employment (e.g., see folders titled "Basic Skills, Education and Employment," 1979-1985.) There are also files documenting his long working relationship with economist Robert Taggart that include information about efforts made by Mr. Berlin and the Foundation to support the awarding of a MacArthur Fellowship award to Dr. Taggart (1982-1987).

This series of three files contains Mr. Berlin's statement to a joint Congressional and Senate Field Hearing on the subject of youth employment (1983), a draft article titled "Employment and Income Generation, Plant Closings and Worker Ownership" with editorial comments by Susan Berresford (1984), and a speech titled "The Foundation's Youth Work, Service and Learning Strategy: A Site Visit Overview" given to the Trustees before a tour of three youth programs (1985).
Series IV. Subject and Correspondence Files, 1982-1987

This series contains chronologically arranged correspondence files and alphabetically arranged subject files. Topics of subject files include the appointment of consultants (1982) and affirmative action (1985).

processinfo.head: Processing Information Note
processinfo.p: The original volume of 6 cubic feet accessioned by the Ford Foundation Archives in 2011 has been reduced during processing to 2.8 cubic feet.

Mr. Berlin grouped multiple folders relating to a specific subject together under overarching subject headings such as Basic Skills, Education and Employment, and Job Training. This filing system was maintained and related folders were kept together under Mr. Berlin's original subject headings.
Duplicates, reference files, form rejection letters for unsolicited grant requests, and documents focused on purely financial matters were not retained.

separatedmaterial.p: Appendix A: Reports â€“ Unpublished reports written by Ford Foundation staff and consultants were removed from their original folders, scanned and transferred to the Archives' collection of staff and consultant reports. userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Completion of a use agreement is required prior to providing scholarly access. See RAC Head of Reference (or applicable designee) for details. Ford Foundation holds title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them. The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection for scholarly purposes. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records more than 10 years old are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.
